body:
while i agree in principle i always find this to be a bit of a naive statement.

it's impossible to categorize actions (or inaction) into things that hurt people and things that don't. there's too much gray area and it's all subjective.

like you've got things that hurt people, but help people too (e.g. driving a car contributes to climate change and road traffic accidents, but it also enables people to do things like do better charity work, or visit family etc).

or you've got things that don't hurt people, but people perceive as hurting them (e.g. should i be allowed to have tattoos even though there are people out there that are scared of people with tattoos?).

and you've got things that do hurt people, but people perceive as not hurting them (e.g. a lot of people have no issue with gambling, even though it's one of the more prevalent addictions around the world).

life is just a bit messy all around really, and while it's a bit of a cop out for me to just sit here and go 'it's tricky', that's about all i've got. i think though that people should always be wary of solutions that sound simple (like 'freedom is more important than anything else', or 'don't do bad things') because they can almost always be used to justify things that you don't actually agree with.

> ...i think those same meteorologists (federal meteorologists) wouldn’t agree with the fact that you said “it’s all climate change”, because we know it’s not all from that.

to be clear, just in case i'm misunderstanding your point—when i said "it's all climate change," i didn't mean that every bad thing about the weather is caused by anthropogenic climate change. i was responding directly to the question of "how is the weather so political?" — forecasting is politicized by people on the right who get angry that science doesn't agree with how they want the world to be.

these are "the 'govt = socialism' air-heads [who] are putting lives in danger" from the grandfather comment [above](

while i’m not disagreeing with you, i think those same meteorologists wouldn’t agree with the fact that you said “it’s all climate change”, because we know it’s not all from that. it without a doubt has, and will, make a difference, but not “everything”.
it is now. it wasn't necessary before. climate change has fucked that for them.

the fact that climate change does not mean hotter weather all the time.

reality of climate change, vaccinations are not a government plot, there is no jewish run world government cabal, evs do not have worse lifecycle emissions than internal combustion vehicles - you know all the standard school yard level rubbish that goes on when people don't understand science.

> how is the weather so political?

it's climate change. it's all climate change. 

federal mets, being researchers and scientists, tend to accept anthropogenic climate change as fact, and that fact occasionally comes up. 

local talking-head forecasters, on the other hand, often mirror their area's prevailing opinion on climate change, and it's not uncommon in conservative markets to have local forecasters who abuse their public platform to disparage climate change and spread misinformation.

the largest ones are out west. as a generalization, business interests and other folks in red states in the west resent this and would like to do more and more mining, drilling, grazing, tree harvesting and other types of despoiling on these lands. another aspect of their distain for climate change science. it is another important reason to vote against these interests

>3m's chemical plant in cordova, illinois released 73 tons of perfluoromethane (cf4) into the atmosphere, more than any other industrial facility in the county, in 2021. cf4 is 7,380 times more potent than carbon dioxide as a greenhouse gas and remains in the atmosphere for 50,000 years. credit: phil mckenna

73 tons x 7,380 = 538,740 tons c02 equivalent
found cost ~$50-200 per ton... so they're pushing ~$25-100mil of cost on us while they profit.

don't be gullible and believe the article is accurate. the **bill** is actually expected to reduce carbon emissions by 7-9%. this authors and editors of the article are either ignorant or lying. 

***"the bill is .....  is expected to slash the country’s planet-warming carbon emissions by about 40% this decade. "***

the 40% reduction is the difference between 2005 emissions and projected 2030 emissions. the secular trend was for a 30% reduction by 2030 **without this bill** and that trend was already well underway and established. relative to the ipcc goals, this bill is more baby step than transformational. 

is it a step in the right direction? **yes, absolutely.** 

is it commensurate with what is required to avert climate catastrophe ? **no. absolutely not.**
the company markets some bullshit assumptions on how much utility prices will increase over the contract
we have a consumption crisis.

"***the*** ***bill****, which president joe biden signed into law in august, is the most aggressive climate investment ever taken by congress and* ***is expected to slash the country’s planet-warming carbon emissions by about 40% this decade*** *and move the country toward a net-zero economy by 2050.*"

people need to understand that this article's characterization of the bill is **compete hogwash**. it's dishonest. 

the truth is that the **40% reduction is comparing the 2030 projection to 2005 emission levels** in the united states. 

\~:text=the%20inflation%20reduction%20act%20of,bill%20passed%20their%20top%20priority.

emissions have **already been declining** in the us from 6.75 gigatons in 2005 to 6.00 gigatons in 2019 as a result of transition to renewables. that over 10% reduction already in the bank.

[

the continued secular trend of transition to renewables due to their economic advantage without this bill had the us on track to a 30% reduction in co2 emissions by 2030 **without this bill.** 

**the incremental reduction associated with this bill is roughly 7-9%**. that's a good thing and a step in the right direction. but we need to look at things objectively and realize that **this is not a measure which is commensurate with the objectives the ipcc** has identified as necessary to avert climate catastrophe.

about 6 months of the year we need central heating where i live.

for the month of january, the average high temperature is -11c (daytime high) and the average low temperature (nighttime low) is -21c.

>i do argue that humans effect on that is pretty minimal and that this is just the cycle we are currently in.

the problem is that based on historical data, we're supposed to be in a cooling trend and we're most definitely in a warming trend. the question is why that is.

we're also warming faster than any previously recorded warming trend. again, the question is why.

>my issue with most alternative fuel and subsidizing it is that it isn't better. wind and solar aren't consistent. electric cars aren't practical for long hauling.

wind and solar are consistent with sufficient battery technology. electric cars (and their batteries) were invented simultaneously with gas powered cars (and steam). but, the gas powered cars "won" because their inventors had more money and bought the patents to sit on them. look at how far battery technology has come in the past 20 years and imagine if we'd invested in that the same way we've invested in gas cars over the past 120 years.

also, as far as i'm aware, no hydrogen cars have blown up in any crash testing.

the people who should hate fossil fuels most are those living in cities where the air is clogged by emissions. go watch a documentary on building grand central station or the london underground.
you have got to be kidding me with this graphic….
shake it off, it will be okay.
still waiting for you to learn some chemistry.  and answer simple questions that i asked you you.
a diesel anyday
like what greta
now make the same map for europe by country.  most record highs happened in the past 20 years.

of course they are releasing some soluble co2……..as they warm up. 

that is fundamental.  the solubility of co2 gas in water is a function of its temperature. when surface waters warm during the day….co2 gas comes out of solution.  geeze…..


where do you think all that co2.comes from each spring as an area warms up? the visual example i keep giving …..keeps going right over your head. 

hint: as the temperature increases (due to earth’s annual rotation) co2 gas is released into the atmosphere as per henry’s gas law. a new state of biochemical equilibrium then exists around the increasing temperature. this equilibrium is dynamic. 

i need a fricking chalk board!!
you’d have a tough time getting around if we didn’t subsidize anything.

submission statement,

pertains to collapse because the us in particular has moved on from covid-19 and believes it isn't happening anymore.   this is very similar to climate denialism despite it still happening and the evidence is everywhere.   recently, there was a ny times article about how there are some who are still holding out and wearing masks over covid implying its no big deal.   the general shift is now that covid is over and doesn't matter.   as seen here over 500,000 people have died since may 4th, 2021 to contradict the narrative that we know of by mainstream media.   profit is more important over people.  

the number of deaths may not be the actual numbers and could be much higher.   additionally, this isn't including the various long term effects of covid which is causing is having far reaching consequences for those that still have it and could lead to many people not being able to work as result, causing a further strain on society itself and accelerating collapse.  

but sometimes making $$$$$ is more important and this outweighs human lives a bit like climate change.

my parents are the only people who have any money currently to adjust our family's lives to the unraveling reality, they understand climate change...and yet they insist on living in fucking tucson az.

im an otr trucker these past 5 years, i see these rivers/reservoirs drying up with an unparalleled rapidity, and i've harped on it in 30 phone calls "hey, you lose water in tucson, and your home becomes worthless" at the same time with houses with far better access to water, quadruple+ in price as everyone else figures it out...

and they just don't listen "well your dad and me decided back in the 70's this is where we wanted to retire".

my whole point is, retirement needs a modicum of stability, and when taps get shut off enmasse, that is the exact polar opposite of stable retirement, they are forced into being nomads from where they thought they wanted to retire, at advanced age.

i don't know how to communicate it to them, my parents are intelligent, but i can clearly see normalcy bias in them on this front, and it's just appalling at the hubris and incompetence on this specific issue they engage in when i know they know better and understand the situation that is unraveling. even without climate change, that region of the country was never going to be long term stable for multiple 10 million industrialized human beings to have long term sustainable life styles or a place to settle down and retire in.

> im just your average joe so really ignorant about the climate and the future because im buried in my work for almost 16 hours a day just to eke out a living.

that's fine; we were all there at some point. anyone who says they didn't start off from the same square as you has forgotten or is lying.

> but i'm starting to question why i keep doing it and for what? what's the point off it all?

frankly, those are questions you should ask *anyway*. you don't want to be one of those people who looks back on their life in their eighties and thinks "wow, that was a waste."

> am i correct to believe that shit wont probably hit the fan until maybe 2100 when most of the earth becomes too hot to live?

god, i wish i could say yes, but the answer is no. it won't be like in the movies; one day everyone is a-ok, just like now, keeping on keeping on, and then bam! the fire nation attacks and everything changes. no, that's not what will happen. instead things will just get slowly worse and worse, the systems getting more and more strained (a failed harvest driving up the price of bread here, another driving up the price of rice there, a heat wave killing several thousand people in a third place, and so on), until one day they can't bear it anymore and then they implode. the saying is "collapse happens very slowly, then very quickly."

> i'll probably wont live long enough til then so i should be fine right?

nope. in the period august 2019 to around january 2020, australia's east coast was blanketed in smoke. people died just from breathing it in - and it was from a series of fires that wouldn't have been that bad if it wasn't for climate change. it's happening *now*. people are already dying from it. and its getting progressively worse. the consequences are already arriving; as a rather dismal tweet put it, we have had the misfortune to be born at the end of the "fuck around" century, and now we are living in the "find out" century.

> so why are people worried? is it those tipping points and feedback loops? or is the 10s of billions of people needing food, water, shelter and oil?

there are as many answers to these questions as there are people on the sub. but if i was to hazard a guess, it would be this; everyone likes to watch a good disaster movie. we all enjoy watching the rock pilot a helicopter while la shakes and dances underneath him. but no-one wants to live through one - because most people die screaming.

> are we going to make it til 2100? just give me the truth i can handle it.

define "we". the actuarial tables say that, regardless, most of us will die before then, but some - especially gen z - might well make it. if things were normal. but things aren't normal anymore. if you mean "we" as in "our civilisation"... no.

>and i would say that in a big part of the country’s having kids would be illegal or at least you need to donate a big amount of money to help the climate change so having kids would be a luxury for only the rich ones.

i'm going to disagree on that one.  in most of the developed world, population growth would be negative if not for immigration.  average fertility rates might go down just because people can't afford the costs associated with raising children, but i don't think a 0-child policy would work basically anywhere.  kids grow into adults that are the labor force, if there's no replacement there's (eventually) no economy.

some countries may experiment with something like china's 1 child policy or a 2 kids max policy, but i expect such things to be highly unpopular with the public (to the extent they have a choice).

as for my predictions: mass climate migrations.  major social friction between nimbys who, for instance, prefer their lifestyle living on an 80-acre farm in central british columbia and don't want it to turn into an urban center, and \~40 million californians (or maybe a lot less, by then, if they've already moved) who want to live in a place with a reliable source of water.

i'm expecting sky-high real estate prices an mass homelessness in oregon, washington, and british columbia as those regions fail to relax their zoning to allow new construction.

(i'm in oregon, so it's the area i'm familiar with.  i'd expect similar things in other regions.)

as i suggested, if you want to leave that bubble listen to a few first episodes of breaking down collapse. just delete your facebook account as soon as yesterday. we are reaching many many tipping points in the availability of resources (from oil through sand to water), climate is in a very bad state and there are many accelerating factors on the horizon, food shortage caused by climate change but also via overuse of available resources (your grandkids will not eat fish anymore), devastation if lora and fauna (extinction of all animals from insects to mammals) and so on... why the richies don't give a fuck? because they will be the last to feel the consequences and at this point it is clear that very deep systemic changes in our behaviour can only get us out of this mess. who has the balls to do that?

the problem is the term global warming implied uniform distribution of warming, hence the 1.5c 'budget'. even the term "global warming" was too disturbing for republican white america in the 1990's and it got changed to 'climate change', to obfuscate the meaning, to make it more mellow. the reality is that the mechanism is irreversible chaotic global warming. there is nothing uniform about it, it is going to be wild beyond imagination. there is virtually no one on the street knowing what the chaos function is, an impulse spike with probabalistic appearance, distribution, location, duration, magnitude.  
  
the simple depiction is the canary in coal mine countries. the desertification band around the equator is going to become wider and wider, with summers that will make then uninhabitable, the populations needing to push north because the remaining fresh water and temperate climates will be north. similar conditions will be there in the south but on the shores of antarctica, that are starting to be exposed now with all the ice melting. there is no land route to antarctica.  
  
the problem is all everybody heard was "be fruitful and multiply!". that was the worst suggestion/order/purpose for the human ape, guaranteeing extinction.  
population > resources = extinction

it use to be called global warming and now it’s climate change. 60 years ago it use to be ‘global cooling’. the truth is that scientist rely too much on models. there’s been research that glaciers are slowing down their shrinkage based on the marks left on the ocean floor.

it is, because it is evidence that the climate can change, in dramatic ways and it isn't possible to blame humans for it.  i'd be more interested to understand that than a few degrees over 100 years.

the weather has gotten so much crazier than several decades ago. 

i lived in a temperate climate. it rarely snowed and the summers were mild. now there are fires and people dying from heat every year and several blizzards. it's madness. 

when i was a kid, it was a huge deal that we had one blizzard. the city didn't even have a snowplow! and now we casually get that amount of snow several times each winter?!

people who are in denial of climate change should be offered free classes to catch them up on modern science. because there is no denying it anymore. you only have to look at the data.
it was clever of the scientists to change from global warming to climate change, since they realized that it would be getting colder than normal sometimes.

we should all ask as well what the role is of the sun and its multiple cycles (the most known being the 11 year cycle, but the sun has loads more) add to that the role l of the milkyway and its magnetic fields. volcano eruptions can have massive effects on the climate. just to name a few examples

it makes my opinion that our climate change understanding is way too oversimplified and loads more variables should be taken into account.

exactly this. in the 11 years i lived in houston, i experienced i think 6 of the 10 costliest storms in recorded history? and my parents who still live there are somehow climate change deniers.

because, at bottom, climate change is a thermodynamic process - more energy going in than coming out (and this is directly measurable). the laws of thermodynamics are foundational to the universe, never, ever, ever violated. climate scientists argue about rate and effects of change, not the cause. alien abduction is actually rather more likely.
as some who actually lives in this area. it is very common for us to get these types of storms. this has nothing to do with "climate change". please just stop

first off, let's start with a source that isn't from 2004, *18 fucking years ago.* [this study]( published in 2021 by colorado state university show a clear increase in the yearly number of tropical cyclones from 2000 to 2021, with 2005 and 2019 having the highest number of recorded storms in history. in the last 20 years tropical cyclones become somewhat more frequent, as well as becoming larger and more damaging, "over the 39-year period from 1979-2017, the number of major hurricanes has increased while the number of smaller hurricanes has decreased" (center center for climate and energy solutions, data recorded by pnas). hurricanes require warm sea temperatures to form, and as the earth continues to heat up, the oceans obviously will too.
research data yourself instead of parroting a bullshit "narrative" from grifters like joe rogan and his buddies.

sources: 

 (colorado state university, 2021)

 center for climate and energy solutions)

 (james p. kossin, kenneth r. knapp, timothy l. olander, and christopher s. velden, 2020)

if a belief is centered around emotional attachments in the form of core beliefs and/or group belonging, logic has *no* say in it. 

feeling dictate decisions far more than thinking ever does. where people land tend to be at the mercy of coincidence, which group they fell in with by birth or socialization. if you are lucky you end up on the side science agrees with.

half a century of military funded studies into how to convince people and change their minds went nowhere until someone figured out that the only reliable way to change someone opinion is to change how they feel about the issue first. 

and the more people care about an issue, the more feelings rule over the matter. 

in these cases the intellect instead becomes weaponized. they use it to reason their way towards the answer they want. which is fairly standard practice for humanity. we get a lot of practice doing this in our daily life on various scales and subjects. 

we also do this for moral matters. i think there was a study they might have called "are the shoes cute?" which showed that people who ahead of the experiment said they were very concerned about ethical practices, workers rights and environmentalism would actively avoid information about a product they liked and wanted for themselves. they avoided it because they did not want to find out negative information and be forced to choose between the product and their moral sense. 

this explains quite a lot about human history. 

there are also people who are smart in one particular way that gets categorized as intellectual by society, and might get an inflated sense of what their abilities outside their expertise is. that for example an engineering degree can somehow equal or supersede a doctorate degree in climate science. 

and some who have completed degrees did so by regurgitating information and textbook answers, and may not themselves be that sharp with things that require deeper thinking. while also confusing this type of ability for general high intelligence. or wisdom.

man i’ve got a coworker that openly looks at oan from his desk and told me the covid vaccine is bad for me. he has a mechanical engineering degree and works for a battery startup. he also doesn’t fully accept human induced climate change.

as a geologist, "i'm an engineer and... " has been a classic opening to climate-change-denial bs for decades. 

engineers are experts in very specific fields but, even more-so than a chemist or biologist or any other "science type" often have educations hyper-focused on that specific field that neglect broader critical thinking and argumentation skills. the majority are smart enough to recognise their own limitations but enough fall into "i'm an expert in all-things-science" that it becomes a common issue.

>because russian really, really needs that oil

i've been calling ukraine a climate change war since march.  i still haven't met another who sees it for what it is.  russia is in deep shit.  the future for oil is not good.  it won't go away, but it won't be the ultra high value commodity it is now in the next 50 years (barring a major disaster).

i think you're pretty much right.  putin is playing the hand he has.  i think he went after ukraine for the resources.  and i think we're going to see a lot more of this as climate changes continues to disrupt our established economies.

i'm also deeply concerned that this is how climate change kills us.  it isn't the warming.  we can adapt.  it isn't the sea level changes.  we can adapt.  it's those things + modern weaponry, specifically nuclear.

feeding the hungry; housing,  educating and offering decent health care to the poor and addressing climate change are  all much cheaper and much more readily achievable. i'd settle for those. compared to a typical large war, they're incredible value for money.

the appointment of marina silva as brazil's next minister of environment and climate change by president-elect luiz inácio lula da silva indicates a commitment to cracking down on illegal deforestation, even if it means going against powerful agribusiness interests. silva's previous tenure as minister of environment saw a drop in deforestation and the creation of numerous conservation areas, as well as the implementation of satellite surveillance and operations against environmental criminals. however, silva is likely to face resistance from congress, particularly from the farm caucus, who may view her appointment as conflicting with their interests. silva's appointment also marks a significant shift from the policies of outgoing president jair bolsonaro, who favored development in the amazon and weakened environmental agencies. brazil's commitment to preserving the amazon, the world's largest rainforest and a crucial component in combating climate change, will be crucial in the fight against global warming.
